maml:description.maml:para: This command adds the current file path to the current project list.

This command adds the current file path to the current project list. The list is simply a text file with full file names to a group of scripts that you might be working on. The ISEScriptingGeek module uses a built-in variable, $currentProjectList.

Add an ISE Bookmark

Convert aliases to their definition.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a command to a hashtable
This is a crude attempt to convert a selected PowerShell expression into a corresponding hashtable that you can use for splatting.
Convert command from an alias
Convert a command from an alias.
Convert from a multi-line comment
Use this command to toggle between a multi-line comment.
Convert MAML help to comment-based help
This function will make a best effort to convert help from an existing cmdlet to comment based help. This is handy when building a proxy function. Converted help will be opened in a new ISE Tab.
Convert aliases to definitions.
Converts all command aliases in selected text to their corresponding command definition.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a string to convert
Enter a string to convert

maml:description.maml:para: Convert to a multi-line comment.
Convert selected text into a multi-line comment.
Convert the file to a text file
Save the current file as a txt file with an option to reload in the PowerShell ISE.
Copy selected text to Microsoft Word
Use this command to copy selected text from the ISE into a new Microsoft Word document. You must have Microsoft Word installed.
Edit the current project list file

Open the current project list in the PowerShell ISE to view or edit. You will need to manually remove items. The list is simply a text file with full file names to a group of scripts that you might be working on.
The ISEScriptingGeek module uses a built-in variable, $currentProjectList.
Edit an ISE Snippet
View snippets and edit selected in the PowerShell ISE. Changes won't be effective until the next ISE session or tab.
Search for text in selected files.
Search for text in selected files.
Profile a PowerShell script

This script will parse a PowerShell script using the AST to identify elements and any items that might be dangerous. The output is a text report which by default is turned into a help topic stored in your Windows PowerShell folder under Documents, although you can specify an alternate location.

DETAILS The script takes the name of a script to profile. You can specify a ps1 or psm1 filename. Using the AST the script will prepare a text report showing you any script requirements, script parameters, commands and type names. You will see all commands used including those that can't be resolved as well as those that I thought might be considered potentially dangerous such as cmdlets that use the verbs Remove or Stop.
Because some people might invoke methods from .NET classes directly I've also captured all typenames. Most of them will probably be related to parameters but as least you'll know what to look for.

The report won't detail parameters from nested functions but you'll still see what commands they will use. The script uses Get-Command to identify commands which might entail loading a module. Most of the time this shouldn't be an issue but you still might want to profile the script in virtualized or test environment.

Any unresolved command you see is either from a module that couldn't be loaded or it might be an internally defined command. Once you know what to look for you can open the script in your favorite editor and search for the mystery commands.
Note that if the script uses application names like Main or Control for function names, they might be misinterpreted. In that case, search the script for the name, ie "main".
This version will only analyze files with an extension of .ps1, .psm1 or .txt.

command:parameter.maml:name: Path

maml:Description.maml:para: The path to the script file. It should have an extension of .ps1, .psm1 or .bat.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: $(Read-Host "Enter the filename and path to a PowerShell script")

maml:Description.maml:para: The path for the report file. The default is your WindowsPowerShell folder. This parameter has aliases of fp and out.

command:parameter.maml:name: Path

maml:Description.maml:para: The path to the script file. It should have an extension of .ps1, .psm1 or .bat.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: $(Read-Host "Enter the filename and path to a PowerShell script")

maml:Description.maml:para: The path for the report file. The default is your WindowsPowerShell folder. This parameter has aliases of fp and out.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This will analyze the script UnknownScript.ps1 and show the results in a help window. It will also create a text file in your Documents\WindowsPowerShell folder called UnknownScript.help.txt.
This command is the same as the first example except the help file will be created in C:\Work.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a proxy function of a PowerShell command.

This command will create a proxy version of a PowerShell cmdlet, function or alias. The intent is to simplify creating a new function from command metadata. You can give your command and opt to remove help references for the original command.
If you run this in the PowerShell ISE, code for the new function will be inserted into a new Powershell tab.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of a PowerShell command to proxy. This can be a cmdlet, function or alias.
The name you want to use for your new command.
Remove references to existing command help. Using this parameter will insert a comment-based help outline.
The name of a PowerShell command to proxy. This can be a cmdlet, function or alias.
The name you want to use for your new command.
Remove references to existing command help. Using this parameter will insert a comment-based help outline.

maml:alert.maml:para: This command was first described at http://jdhitsolutions.com/blog/2014/09/friday-fun-creating-powershell-scripts-with-powershell

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a proxy function for Get-WMIObject that will be called Get-MyOS. Help references will be replaced with a comment-help block.

maml:description.maml:para: Get an ISE Bookmark.
Get an ISE Bookmark
Get the next ISE tab.
Use this command to easily cycle through open tabs in the ISE.
Get comments from a PowerShell script file.
This command will use the AST parser to go through a PowerShell script, either a .ps1 or .psm1 file, and display only the comments.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the path of a PS1 file
Enter the path of a PS1 file

maml:description.maml:para: Get about scripting help
Use this command to select about_scripting topics using Out-Gridview.
Search for selected text online
Use this command to search online for the selected text. The default is Google.
Open files from the project list

Read the current project list and open each file in the ISE. The list is simply a text file with full file names to a group of scripts that you might be working on. The ISEScriptingGeek module uses a built-in variable, $currentProjectList.
Create a command based on a CIM class.
This command starts a graphical wizard process to help you build a new function based on a WMI/CIM class.
Auto-generate comment based help.
This will generate comment based help based on a loaded command and insert it into the current file in the ISE.

maml:description.maml:para: Create ISE snippets for DSC Resources

This command will convert the syntax for a DSC resource into an ISE snippet. Snippets will be created in the default location. Snippet names will take the name "DSC <resource name>". The snippet description uses the format "<Resource Name> resource from module <module name> <vendor>".You will end up with a description like this:
xWinEventLog resource from module xWinEventLog Microsoft Corporation
You must run this command in the PowerShell ISE.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the name of a DSC resource
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the name of a DSC resource
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Enter the name of a DSC resource
Enter the name of a DSC resource
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> New-DSCResourceSnippet -name xsmbshare -author "Jeff Hicks" -passthru
Directory: C:\Users\Jeff\documents\WindowsPowerShell\Snippets
Mode LastWriteTime Length Name ---- ------------- ------ ---- -a--- 10/20/2014 8:48 AM 1157 DSC xSmbShare Resource.snippets.ps1xml

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create a snippet from a single resource.
This command will create snippets for every installed DSC resource. Existing snippet files will be overwritten.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new file in the current path.

When you create a new file, the ISE wants to create it in the directory you were in when you started the ISE. I often want to create a new file in the current location. This command has no parameters. You will be prompted for a new file name if you don't specify one.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter the name of the new file. If you don't specify one you will be prompted.
Enter the name of the new file. If you don't specify one you will be prompted.

maml:description.maml:para: Insert a function outline
Use this command to insert a function outline. This is very similar to using the function snippet.
Display a Visual Basic style inputbox.

This function will display a graphical Inputbox, like the one from VisualBasic and VBScript. You must specify a messag prompt. You can specify a title, the default is "Input". You can also specify a default value. The inputbox will write whatever is entered into it to the pipeline. If you click Cancel the inputbox will still write a string to the pipeline with a length of 0. It is recommended that you validate input.

maml:Description.maml:para: Enter a message prompt
Enter a message prompt

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $c = New-Inputbox -prompt "Enter the Netbios name of a domain computer." -title "Enter a computername" -default $env:computername PS C:\> get-service -computer $c

maml:description.maml:para: Create an advanced function outline
This command will create the outline of an advanced function based on a hash table of new parameter values. You will still need to flesh out the function and insert the actual commands.
You might need to tweak parameters in the resulting code for items such a default value, help message, parameter aliases and validation.
The New-PSCommand command takes a lot of the grunt work out of the scripting process so you can focus on the actual working part of the function.

maml:Description.maml:para: The name of the new function

A hash table of new parameter values. The key should be the parameter name. The entry value should be the object type. You can also indicate if it should be an array by using [] with the object type. Here's an example:
@{Name="string[]";Test="switch";Path="string"}
Or you can use an "advanced" version of the hash table to specify optional parameter attributes that follows the format:
@{ParamName="type[]",Mandatory,ValuefromPipeline,ValuefromPipelinebyPropertyName,Position}
Here's an example:
$h = @{Name="string[]",$True,$True,$False,0; Path="string",$false,$false,$false,1; Size="int",$false,$false,$true; Recurse="switch" }
You can also specify an ordered hash table if you are running PowerShell v or later.
Provide a brief synopsis of your command.
Provide a description for your command. You can always add and edit this later.
A block of code to insert in the Begin scriptblock. This can be either a scriptblock or a string.
A block of code to insert at the start of the Process scriptblock. This can be either a scriptblock or a string.
A block of code to insert at the start of the End scriptblock. This can be either a scriptblock or a string.
Set SupportsShouldProcess to True in the new function.
If you are running this command in the ISE, send the new function to the editor as a new file.
The name of the new function

A hash table of new parameter values. The key should be the parameter name. The entry value should be the object type. You can also indicate if it should be an array by using [] with the object type. Here's an example:
@{Name="string[]";Test="switch";Path="string"}
Or you can use an "advanced" version of the hash table to specify optional parameter attributes that follows the format:
@{ParamName="type[]",Mandatory,ValuefromPipeline,ValuefromPipelinebyPropertyName,Position}
Here's an example:
$h = @{Name="string[]",$True,$True,$False,0; Path="string",$false,$false,$false,1; Size="int",$false,$false,$true; Recurse="switch" }
You can also specify an ordered hash table if you are running PowerShell v or later.
Set SupportsShouldProcess to True in the new function.
Provide a brief synopsis of your command.
Provide a description for your command. You can always add and edit this later.
A block of code to insert in the Begin scriptblock. This can be either a scriptblock or a string.
A block of code to insert at the start of the Process scriptblock. This can be either a scriptblock or a string.
A block of code to insert at the start of the End scriptblock. This can be either a scriptblock or a string.
If you are running this command in the ISE, send the new function to the editor as a new file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $paramhash=@{Name="string[]";Test="switch";Path="string"} PS C:\> New-PSCommand -name "Set-MyScript" -Newparameters $paramhash | out-file "c:\scripts\set-myscript.ps1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create an advanced script outline for Set-MyScript with parameters of Name, Test and Path. Results are saved to a file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> $hash = [ordered]@{Name="string[]",$True,$True,$False,0;Path="string",$false,$false,$false,1;Size="int",$false,$false,$true;Recurse="switch"}
PS C:\> $begin={ #initialize some variables $arr=@() $a=$True $b=123 } PS C:\> $end="write-host 'Finished' -foreground Green" PS C:\> $synopsis = "Get user data" PS C:\> $desc = @" This command will do something really amazing. All you need to do is provide the right amount of pixie dust and shavings from a unicorn horn.
This requires PowerShell v4 and a full moon. "@
PS C:\> New-PSCommand -Name Get-UserData -NewParameters $hash -BeginCode $begin -EndCode $end -Synopsis $synopsis -Description $desc -useise

dev:remarks.maml:para: Create an advanced function from the ordered hash table. This expression will also insert extra code into the Begin and End scriptblocks as well as enter text for the help synopsis and description. The new command will be opened in the ISE.

maml:description.maml:para: Open an ISE bookmark.
Open an ISE bookmark.
Open selected file in an ISE tab
Open selected file in a PowerShell ISE tab. You can use this to open dot sourced files in a script or profile. Select the entire path and use this command or it's shortcut to open the file.
Send command output to an ISE tab
This command will accept pipelined input and place it in a new PowerShell ISE tab.

maml:Description.maml:para: Insert the text into the current ISE tab.
Insert the text into the current ISE tab.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> get-process | sort WS -descending | Select -first 5 | out-isetab

maml:description.maml:para: Delete an ISE bookmark.
Delete an ISE bookmark.

Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:description.maml:para: Reload a file in the PowerShell ISE
This command will reload an file in the ISE that might have been modified outside of the ISE.
Print the current file in the ISE.
This function is intended to be used in the ISE to print the current script file to the default printer.
Set location to current script folder.
Use this command to change location to match that of the current script in the PowerShell ISE.
Launch the current script file
Use this command to launch the current script file with Show-Command. Fill in the form to run the script.
Update an ISE Bookmark.
Update an ISE Bookmark.
Sign a script with verified certificate.
Use this command to easily sign a script file with a valid code signing certificate.
